items.title: Israel clears final hurdle to start constructing controversial West Bank settlement project
items.summary_auto: Israel has cleared the final hurdle before starting construction on a contentious settlement project near Jerusalem that would effectively cut the occupied West Bank in two, according to a government tender.

items.title: Jury hears opposing narratives of officer's actions during deadly Texas school shooting
items.summary_auto: The trial of one of the first police officers on the scene of the deadly 2022 attack at a Texas elementary school opened on Tuesday with prosecutors accusing him of criminally failing to try to stop the slaughter, while the defence said the officer did the best he could at the chaotic and confusing scene.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | Tech highlights from CES 2026
items.summary_auto: Companies both large and small are giving the public a first look at their new products during CES 2026, the world's largest consumer technology trade show, now underway in Las Vegas.

items.title: Air Transat pilots vote to ratify new five-year deal
items.summary_auto: 91 per cent of Air Transat pilots who voted agreed to ratify a new five-year employment contract with the airline. The union and company reached the tentative deal in December, narrowly avoiding a strike.

items.title: Kazuma Okamoto 'very happy' to join Blue Jays team with sights set on World Series title
items.summary_auto: The six-time all-star with the Yomiuri Giants of Nippon Professional Baseball told reporters Tuesday that he plans to work hard every single day and do his best for the team, which is firmly eyeing a return to the World Series.

items.title: Nestlé recall of some baby formulas does not apply to Canadian products, company says
items.summary_auto: Nestlé voluntarily recalled a number of baby formula batches due to potential contamination with a toxin that can cause severe vomiting and nausea. The recall applies to products sold in a number of countries, mostly within Europe, but the company says Canada is not affected.

items.title: Who controls Venezuela’s oil? It’s complicated
items.summary_auto: With the U.S. now claiming control of Venezuela, Donald Trump says oil companies will rush in to build up the infrastructure and earn huge profits. But Venezuela has a history of seizing American assets and kicking U.S. companies out, leaving the future of the oil industry uncertain.

items.title: Nova Scotia boy attacked by 3 dogs has died
items.summary_auto: The Tri-County Regional Centre for Education says the loss of the 13-year-old student will be felt widely.

items.title: Woman pleads guilty to 6 counts of assault in Vancouver seawall stabbings
items.summary_auto: Tamara Hamelin, 35, was charged with four counts of assault with a weapon and two counts of assault in relation to a series of stabbing attacks in Vancouver's Yaletown neighbourhood last October. She pleaded guilty to the offences last month.

items.title: Ford's annual U.S. sales rise 6% on strong sales for affordable trucks and hybrid cars
items.summary_auto: Slowing sales of electric vehicles were offset by an uptick in demand for its more affordable Maverick truck, and for hybrid vehicles.

items.title: One of Quebec's most wanted fugitives arrested in Spain
items.summary_auto: Juan Pablo Serrano, wanted since June 2024 in connection with a massive Desjardins data breach, was arrested by Spanish authorities, according to Quebec provincial police.

items.title: Fugitive wanted in connection with Desjardins data breach arrested in Spain
items.summary_auto: Juan Pablo Serrano, wanted since June 2024 in connection with a massive Desjardins data breach, was arrested by Spanish authorities, according to Quebec provincial police.

items.title: Ontario's new online courts portal is causing delays, bogging down system, Toronto lawyers say
items.summary_auto: A new online portal meant to streamline access to Ontario's court system is leaving some lawyers grappling with unpredictable delays and facing new hurdles in managing their cases, they say months after the platform's initial rollout.

items.title: Hospital ER in 100 Mile House, B.C., closes temporarily for 2nd time in 2026
items.summary_auto: For the second time in less than a week, the emergency department at the hospital in the district municipality of 100 Mile House was closed temporarily as the mayor of the community in British Columbia’s South Cariboo region calls for meaningful long-term solutions.

items.title: After runner-up finish, Charles Milliard tries again for Quebec Liberal leadership
items.summary_auto: Charles Milliard, the former CEO of Quebec's federation of chambers of commerce and a pharmacist by training, said he would work to restore the Liberal party’s standing in Quebec politics.

items.title: Orcas spotted rubbing bellies on rocks near shore in Gibsons, B.C.
items.summary_auto: A pod of orcas surprised people on B.C. 's Sunshine Coast earlier this month by swimming close to shore and rubbing their bellies on the rocks — a behaviour an expert says few killer whales around the world have been observed doing.

items.title: ‘Very unique’: Pod of killer whales seen rubbing bellies on rocks off B.C.'s Sunshine Coast
items.summary_auto: A pod of orcas surprised people on B.C. 's Sunshine Coast earlier this month by swimming close to shore and rubbing their bellies on the rocks — a behaviour an expert says few killer whales around the world have been observed doing.

items.title: Dozens of Regina passengers arrive in Mexico without luggage as WestJet reports baggage issues
items.summary_auto: Dozens of Regina passengers arrived in Puerto Vallarta without their luggage after WestJet reported baggage issues, leaving travelers scrambling for answers and struggling to locate their bags.

items.title: Trump's Greenland annexation threats overshadow Ukraine security conference
At least 25 people killed in Iranian economic protests, rights groups say
items.summary_auto: At least 25 people have been killed in Iran during the first nine days of protests that started in the bazaar of Tehran over the plunging value of the currency and soaring inflation, according to rights groups.

items.title: Swiss officials can't explain why bar hadn't received fire safety inspection in 6 years ahead of deadly blaze
items.summary_auto: Fire safety inspections hadn't been carried out for several years at the bar where a fire that broke out at a New Year's party left 40 people dead and over 100 injured, local authorities said Tuesday.

items.title: Manitoba cuts ties with dozens of private nursing agencies to curb reliance on the firms
items.summary_auto: A nurse is warning rural hospitals may have an even tougher time filling shifts in the new year as the Manitoba government ends its relationship with dozens of companies supplying its health-care system with agency nurses.

items.title: 'It's like on Amazon': Illegal drugs advertised online, delivered by Canada Post
Yukon trapper Robert Stitt reflects on a solitary life in the bush, and why he's making a change
items.summary_auto: Seventy-five-year-old Robert Stitt’s youthful energy, clear eyes and hearty laugh might perhaps be chalked up to 55 years of trapping: long winter months working outside in the fresh air and sleeping in a remote cabin under the northern lights.

items.title: Amnesty International joins fight for Nova Scotia dump site cleanup and safe water
items.summary_auto: An international organization that often finds itself at the centre of human rights conflicts in developing countries has turned its attention to a small town in southwest Nova Scotia.

items.title: Cheaper obesity medications could come to Canada this summer, as Health Canada reviews generics
items.summary_auto: In Canada, the patent for some semaglutide drugs has expired, paving the way for the country to become the first to offer cheaper generic versions of medications like Ozempic and Wegovy to people with prescriptions. Pharmaceutical experts say this could take some time.

items.title: More oil production in Venezuela could hurt Canada's oilpatch
items.summary_auto: A regime change in Venezuela could both help that country regain its former prominence as an oil producer and pose a threat to Canada’s industry, which is producing record amounts of oil and is expected to continue to grow for several more years.

items.title: #TheMoment skydivers set a new formation record
items.summary_auto: Simon-Pierre Bouchard and Jean-François Denis, skydivers from Quebec, tell The National about the moment they helped set a new canopy formation record with 104 skydivers from around the world.

items.title: B.C. jobs in high demand: Why 2026 may be the best time to learn a trade
items.summary_auto: Amid Prime Minister Mark Carney’s push for nation-building projects and uncertainty around AI’s impact on the job market, an advocate for British Columbia’s construction industry says there’s no better time to consider a career in the trades.

items.title: Eva Schloss, Holocaust survivor and stepsister of Anne Frank, dead at 96
items.summary_auto: Auschwitz survivor Eva Schloss, the stepsister of teenage diarist Anne Frank and a tireless educator about the horrors of the Holocaust, has died. She was 96.
